question: How do you arrange your life so eight hours of sleep outrank eight hours of screens?
answer:
I don’t. But I’m working on it.
I’ve been thinking a lot about this lately, because I have a new job that requires me to be in front of a computer for 8+ hours per day. It’s not the first time I’ve had to deal with this kind of thing, but it is the first time I’ve done it as my primary source of income. And while I know that there are many people who work at jobs like mine and still manage to get their lives together, I also know that there are many more who can’t. So I thought I’d share some thoughts on how I try to make sure that I don’t end up being one of those people.
The first step is to recognize that you’re going to need to change your habits if you want to succeed. This means making sacrifices now, even if they seem small or insignificant. For example, I used to watch TV every night before bed. Now I read instead. That might sound trivial, but it’s actually a big deal when you consider that I was spending an hour watching TV each night before bed, which adds up to over two hours of screen time per week. If I were to continue doing that, I would spend almost three hours of my waking hours staring at a screen each week. That’s a lot of wasted time!
Another way to reduce screen time is to use apps like Freedom or Freedom Time. These apps allow you to set limits on how much time you spend looking at your phone or tablet. They also give you the option to block certain websites from accessing your device. While these apps aren’t perfect (they sometimes fail to detect when someone has accidentally opened a blocked website), they can help you stay focused and avoid distractions.
Finally, remember that technology isn’t always bad. In fact, it can be very helpful in some situations. For instance, I use my laptop to write blog posts and articles. I also use it to research topics for my classes. However, I also use it to watch movies and TV shows. While these activities may not be good for my health, they are still enjoyable and beneficial.
In conclusion, reducing screen time doesn’t mean giving up all forms of entertainment. Instead, it means finding ways to enjoy yourself without sacrificing your health or well-being. By taking steps such as limiting screen time, using apps like Freedom or Freedom Time, and remembering that technology isn’t always bad, you can create a healthier lifestyle that includes both physical activity and mental stimulation.
